data.title: A HATED PRINCESS
data.meta_description: THERE are no people in the world more loyal than the Danes. Denmark's King Christian was one ...
data.text:
THERE are no people in the

world more loyal than the

Danes.

Denmark's King Christian was one

of the best-loved monarchs of his

tory.

But it's Denmark, too, that claims,

most unwillingly, the princess whom

nobody loves.'

Just recently she returned from

exile to visit the bedside of her dying

husband, Prince Harald, brother of

King Christian, and also of King

Haakon, of Norway.

There was no warmth, no wel-

come for her on her return; nothing

but cold, polite formality;

The atmosphere was strangely dif-

ferent from that which first wel-

comed her to Denmark, the gay,

merry German-born Helena, Prin-

cess of Sonderburg-Glucksburg.

It was different, too, from that

in which she had moved in the early

years of her marriage; and in which

she had brought up her children

the Princes Oluf and Gorm, the Prin

cesses Feodora, Carolina Matilda, and

Alexandrina Louisa.

Hatred didn't touch her through

out World War I, when Denmark

preserved an uneasy neutrality.

But when Nazi planes first flew

over Copenhagen, she was lunching .

on the terrace with a group of

friends. She looked up and said:

"Aren't our planes wonderful?''

A Danish officer reproved her. He

said: "Madame,, please remember

that you are now a Danish princess,''.

and left the party.

She entertained . the Nazi con-

querors. She was the one rift in the

lute of the Danish ruling family.

Princess Helena will never be wel-

comed back to Denmark.
